Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EAGER - Managing Uncertainty by Integrating Information Economics and Robust Design

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Early-Concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER)award is to establish the foundations of a method for managing uncertainty within multilevel design processes. Mitigation of uncertainty in designing complex systems typically results in a significant increase in computational cost; efforts to reduce computational effort necessitate the use of simpler models resulting in increased uncertainty. Hence, there is a need to research and develop methods to find the right balance between uncertainty and computational effort while making good design decisions. The central hypothesis is that the effect of uncertainty and its propagation in multilevel design process networks can be managed by balancing the effort of uncertainty mitigation and the benefit gained in terms of system performance. On successful completion this project will provide the foundational knowledge and approaches to managing uncertainty in the multilevel design of complex systems.

If successful, the outcomes of this award will be: a) an approach for quantifying modeling and computational effort; b) an approach for making tradeoff decisions between the effort associated with uncertainty mitigation and design outcomes; c) a framework integrating information economics and robust design; and d) a validated concept that can be used to carry out systematic studies on uncertainty mitigation in simulation-based design of complex engineering systems. The proposed research is transformational because of its focus on uncertainty management through tradeoff between effort and benefit, as opposed to uncertainty mitigation approaches that are characterized solely by the need to increase the accuracy of models in a design process network. Successful demonstration of the proof of concept will result in a foundation upon which more extensive research will be performed and proposed. In addition to publishing in the scholarly literature, the industrially relevant portions of this work will be presented at workshops and trade meetings. The PIs will proactively recruit and mentor underrepresented minorities and women through their activities ASME and SWE student chapters, Pi Tau Sigma, and programs to attract under-represented minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal in this project was to investigate the feasibility of uncertainty management in simulation-based-design through the integration of two core constructs – information economics and robust design. One of the barriers in integrating the two constructs is the lack of ways to model effort associated with gathering additional information. To address this gap, an effort modeling strategy is established in this investigation by extending existing cost models for software development and systems engineering. The model accounts for three aspects of effort: a) efforts associated with gathering and utilizing information to refine the models, b) efforts associated with physical experiments, c) efforts in executing the models. The participants in this project also demonstrated the compatibility of the value of information constructs and robust design constructs for the integrated design of products and materials.

The effort model developed in this project can be used to quantify person hours, computational time, and the monetary cost separately. This allows designers to extract the information that they need without making drastic assumptions about the effort involved in order to refine a model. Approaches for calibration of the model and determining key parameters in the model are presented. The effort model developed in this project enables designers to account for the tradeoff between effort and benefit associated with activities such as model refinement, model selection, and experimentation. The method is generally applicable to various domains of engineering where systems design is driven by simulation models.

This project provided the opportunity for one graduate student to perform research on his MS Thesis. The outcomes of this project are included in a graduate-level course jointly taught by the PIs at Washington State University and Oklahoma University during Fall 2011. The students from both universities participated in joint lectures and collaborative projects.
